rules.name: Daily Wound Care / Skin Substitute Billing
rules.logic: If wound care codes billed on 5+ consecutive days with 80%+ round-dollar amounts, flag as medically implausible
rules.medical_standard: Skin grafts require 14-28 days healing between applications to same site
rules.explain_short: Daily consecutive skin graft billing (medically impossible)
rules.explain_deep: Provider billed wound care codes {codes} on {n} consecutive days totaling ${amount}. Medical standard requires 14-28 day healing intervals. Peer baseline: {peer_freq} per patient per year.
investigation_steps: Request wound bed photographs with measurements for each date
Verify distinct anatomical sites if multiple same-day grafts
Review treatment plans and medical necessity documentation
Check for duplicate billing to same member

rules.name: Modifier-59 Systematic Unbundling
rules.logic: If modifier-59 used on >60% of claims when peer baseline is 8-15%, flag systematic unbundling
rules.explain_short: Systematic use of modifier-59 to unbundle services
rules.explain_deep: Provider uses modifier-59 on {pct}% of claims vs peer baseline {peer_pct}%. Pattern indicates unbundling of add-on or bundled services. Common combinations: {codes}.
investigation_steps: Review operative notes for distinct procedures
Verify separate anatomical sites justify modifier-59
Check time separation between procedures
Compare to CCI edits and bundling rules
rules.bundling_rules: Sedation (99152) typically bundled with procedure payment. Add-on codes (64484) should only use -59 for anatomically distinct sites.

rules.name: Round-Number Anchoring
rules.logic: If 25%+ of billed amounts are round numbers (end in 00 or 000), above peer baseline of 12%, flag cognitive bias or template billing
rules.explain_short: Excessive round-dollar amounts indicate template billing
rules.explain_deep: Round-number frequency {pct}% vs peer {peer_pct}%. Real medical billing varies by time, supplies, complexity. Perfect uniformity suggests fabricated charges or cognitive anchoring.
investigation_steps: Request itemized invoices showing time/supply breakdown
Compare to contracted fee schedules
Review for copy-paste documentation patterns

rules.name: Impossible Service Volume
rules.logic: If provider bills >100 claims/month or >10 per day sustained, flag volume anomaly
rules.explain_short: Claim volume exceeds physically possible service capacity
rules.explain_deep: Provider averages {claims_per_day} claims/day vs peer {peer_claims_per_day}. Sustained high volume may indicate auto-submission, cloning, or fabrication.
investigation_steps: Review appointment logs vs billed dates
Check for duplicate member IDs on same dates
Verify provider credentials and license status
Conduct site visit to confirm capacity

rules.name: Same-Day E/M with Procedure (-25)
rules.logic: If E/M codes with modifier-25 paired with procedures same-day at >3x peer rate, flag potential unbundling
rules.explain_short: Excessive same-day E/M billing with procedures
rules.explain_deep: Provider bills E/M with -25 at {rate}% vs peer {peer_rate}%. May indicate billing for E/M already included in procedure global period.
investigation_steps: Verify E/M documentation shows separate, identifiable service
Check for distinct history, exam, and MDM
Review for preventive service exceptions

rules.name: E/M Level Upcoding
rules.logic: If high-level E/M codes (99214-99215) represent >70% of visits vs peer 30%, flag upcoding
rules.explain_short: Disproportionate billing of high-complexity E/M codes
rules.explain_deep: Provider bills level 4-5 E/M at {pct}% vs peer {peer_pct}%. Pattern suggests systematic upcoding without corresponding clinical complexity.
investigation_steps: Audit documentation for MDM complexity
Verify time documentation if time-based billing
Compare diagnosis codes to billed levels
